block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 24, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

FICTION
TWO LITTLE GIRLS IN BLUE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $7.99.) A small girl communicates telepathically with her kidnapped twin.
JUDGE & JURY, by James Patterson and Andrew Gross. (Warner, $9.99.) An aspiring actress and an F.B.I. agent join forces against a powerful mobster.
THE MEMORY KEEPER'S DAUGHTER, by Kim Edwards. (Penguin, $14.) A doctor's decision to secretly send his newborn daughter, who has Down syndrome, to an institution haunts everyone involved.
SHIVER, by Lisa Jackson. (Zebra, $7.99.) A New Orleans detective tracks a serial killer.
MORNING COMES SOFTLY, by Debbie Macomber. (Avon, $7.99.) A reprint of a romance involving a librarian from Louisiana and a Montana rancher.
True believer, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $12.95.) A hip young New Yorker finds love with a beautiful librarian who lives in a North Carolina town.
PRIOR BAD ACTS, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $7.99.) Two Minneapolis detectives search for a kidnapped judge who has been trying a murder case.
A WICKED GENTLEMAN, by Jane Feather. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A cryptic nobleman takes curious interest in a woman's shabby London home (and in her).
HEY, GOOD LOOKING, by Fern Michaels. (Pocket, $7.99.) Family feuds and forgiveness in Baton Rouge.
MCKETTRICK'S PRIDE, by Linda Lael Miller. (HQN, $7.99.) A fiery Chicagoan stirs long-buried feelings of romance in Rance McKettrick.
DEADLY GAME, by Christine Feehan. (Jove, $7.99.) Two Ghostwalkers, one a warrior and assassin, join forces to save victims of a wicked breeding program.
THE KITE RUNNER, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $15.95 and $14.) An Afghan-American returns to Kabul to learn how a childhood friend has fared.
SNOW FLOWER AND THE SECRET FAN, by Lisa See. (Random House, $13.95.) The lives of two women in 19th-century China.
THE NAMESAKE, by Jhumpa Lahiri. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.) Tracing the fortunes of a Bengali-American, Gogol Ganguli.
THE TRAITOR, by Stephen Coonts. (St. Martin's, $7.99.) A C.I.A. officer develops a strategy to infiltrate Al Qaeda and tracks a French agent with Middle Eastern entanglements.
MY SISTER'S KEEPER, by Jodi Picoult. (Washington Square, $14.) A girl sues her parents after learning they want her to donate a kidney to her sibling.

NONFICTION
THE MEASURE OF A MAN, by Sidney Poitier. (HarperSanFrancisco, $14.95.) The movie actor's spiritual autobiography.
THE GLASS CASTLE, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $14.) The author recalls a bizarre childhood during which she and her siblings were constantly moved.
EAT, PRAY, LOVE, by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Penguin Books, $15.) A writer's yearlong journey in search of self takes her to Italy, India and Indonesia.
THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Vintage, $13.95.) The author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband.
90 MINUTES IN HEAVEN, by Don Piper with Cecil Murphey. (Revell, $12.99.) A minister's otherworldly experience after an accident.
STUMBLING ON HAPPINESS, by Daniel Gilbert. (Vintage, $14.95.) A Harvard professor explores why people can't predict what will make them happy.
DREAMS FROM MY FATHER, by Barack Obama. (Three Rivers, $13.95.) Life as the son of a black African father and white American mother.
NIGHT, by Elie Wiesel. (Hill & Wang, $9.) The horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald.
THREE CUPS OF TEA, by Greg Mortenson and David Oliver Relin. (Penguin Books, $15.) A former climber builds schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) A journalist's study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
ZODIAC, by Robert Graysmith. (Berkley, $7.99.) An account of the hunt for a serial killer in California; the basis for the movie of the same title.
RUNNING WITH SCISSORS, by Augusten Burroughs. (Picador, $14 and $7.99.) In the 1970s, a young boy lives with a crazy psychiatrist in a squalid household.
THE POLITICALLY INCORRECT GUIDE TO GLOBAL WARMING AND ENVIRONMENTALISM, by Christopher C. Horner. (Regnery, $19.95.) Debating the causes, extent and effects of climate change.
DON'T MAKE A BLACK WOMAN TAKE OFF HER EARRINGS, by Tyler Perry. (Riverhead, $12.95.) The man behind ''Diary of a Mad Black Woman'' muses on life.
THE PURSUIT OF HAPPYNESS, by Chris Gardner with Quincy Troupe and Mim Eichler Rivas. (Amistad/HarperCollins, $14.95.) Gardner's life story, from a grim childhood to homelessness to success.
THE FREEDOM WRITERS DIARY, by the Freedom Writers with Erin Gruwell. (Broadway, $13.95.) Students considered ''unteachable'' write about their lives; the basis for the movie ''Freedom Writers.''
